docs.abstract: As it aims to stem the flow of migrants from Africa and bring about change in a dictatorship, the European Union is spending millions on projects built by people in forced conscription.
docs.snippet: As it aims to stem the flow of migrants from Africa and bring about change in a dictatorship, the European Union is spending millions on projects built by people in forced conscription.
docs.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union spent 20 million euros last year in Eritrea, hoping to help stem an exodus from the repressive African country, which is consistently one of its biggest sources of asylum seekers.

headline.main: How Forced Labor in Eritrea Is Linked to E.U.-Funded Projects
headline.print_headline: In Eritrea, Paying Forced Laborers With European Funds

docs.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Well. I’ve solved a lot of crossword puzzles, but I can honestly say that I have never solved one that made me tear up when I got the theme.

docs.abstract: Iran said its bombings in Iraq had “concluded proportionate measures” against the United States, but officials around the region said that did not mean it was done maneuvering.
docs.snippet: Iran said its bombings in Iraq had “concluded proportionate measures” against the United States, but officials around the region said that did not mean it was done maneuvering.
docs.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Over an intense half-hour before dawn on Wednesday, Iran bombed targets in Iraq, striking in and around two large military bases that house thousands of Iraqi and American servicemen and women.

docs.abstract: A day after Iranian missiles fell on bases housing American troops in Iraq, the president said that no Americans were harmed and that Iran now “appears to be standing down.”
docs.snippet: A day after Iranian missiles fell on bases housing American troops in Iraq, the president said that no Americans were harmed and that Iran now “appears to be standing down.”
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump backed away from further military action against Iran and called for renewed diplomacy on Wednesday as the bristling confrontation of the past six days eased in the aftermath of an Iranian missile strike that seemed intended to save face rather than inflict casualties.

headline.main: Trump Backs Away From Further Military Conflict With Iran
headline.print_headline: U.S. and Iranians Lower Tensions, at Least For Now

docs.abstract: Legislation to help the children of service members is stalled in committee.
docs.snippet: Legislation to help the children of service members is stalled in committee.
docs.lead_paragraph: By the time most military children complete secondary school, they will have switched schools up to nine times. These frequent changes between schools of strikingly varying quality trouble military children both socially and academically. Though Congress has written legislation that would ease transitions for military children and add flexibility to their parents’ choices for education, the bill, the Education Savings Accounts for Military Families Act of 2019, has sat in committee since March.

headline.main: Military Kids Change School Up to 9 Times. So Let’s Make It Easier.
headline.print_headline: The School Burden Military Kids Face

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: Too few know the history of the Nazi methodical mass murder of disabled people. That is why I write.
docs.snippet: Too few know the history of the Nazi methodical mass murder of disabled people. That is why I write.
docs.lead_paragraph: My first visit to the Aktion T4 killing site at Brandenburg an der Havel was in autumn. My destination, where 9,000 disabled people were murdered as part of the Nazi “euthanasia” program, is embedded in the activities of the town — trams and buses, stores, a bank, a cafe.

headline.main: Before the ‘Final Solution’ There Was a ‘Test Killing’

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

docs.abstract: Not long after her killing, someone left a racist message on my office phone at Barnard, where she had been a student. Why?
docs.snippet: Not long after her killing, someone left a racist message on my office phone at Barnard, where she had been a student. Why?
docs.lead_paragraph: I wasn’t expecting to get any messages on my answering machine at Barnard College on Christmas Day. But there was one. So I hit play, thinking it might be greetings from an old friend, or even a stranger, wishing to share the good will of the season.

headline.main: Tessa Majors and the Worst Thing I Ever Heard
headline.print_headline: The Worst Thing I Ever Heard

docs.abstract: To Save and Project, the annual MoMA series, unearths forgotten work by Australian women, a French auteur and even George A. Romero.
docs.snippet: To Save and Project, the annual MoMA series, unearths forgotten work by Australian women, a French auteur and even George A. Romero.
docs.lead_paragraph: Just because movies spent more than a century as physical objects — as strips of film, not the digital files of the 21st century — doesn’t mean they can’t disappear. And their loss, to decomposition or to memory, inevitably leaves gaps in knowledge.

headline.main: This Festival Could Alter Your Sense of Film History
headline.print_headline: Changing Your Sense Of Cinematic History
